Award.AwardTitle: Self-Exciting Point Processes and Their Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
In mathematics, point processes are pure-jump stochastic processes, which means they are time evolutions that jump at random times and may have random jump sizes. These processes are useful to model the complex systems that arise in the study of sociology, biology, criminology, seismology, finance, and many other fields. The most standard point process is the Poisson process that has independent time increments, which means that future jumps are independent of what has occurred in the past. However, one does not often observe independent time increments in real-world data. For example, as seen during the 2008 financial crisis, credit defaults have a contagion effect -- a default of one company can trigger more companies to default. In social networks, the possibility for users to re-share the content posted by their social connections may cascade across the system. In seismology, after an earthquake hits, the area often experiences aftershocks. In criminology, gang-related violence has the property that a murder or shooting by one gang often provokes retaliation by another gang. All these examples have in common the self-exciting property: an event can trigger more events to come. Self-exciting point processes, the subject of this research project, constitute a class of point processes that can describe such phenomena. Despite their importance in applications, many key central facts are still unknown. This project will investigate the theoretical aspects of self-exciting point processes, as well as their applications. It aims to advance understanding of how complex and large stochastic systems self and mutually excite, interact, cluster, and effect contagion. The results derived from this framework will be applied to better understand the big data sets arising from complex systems in the real world.

More specifically, this project studies a class of self-exciting point processes, with a focus on the Hawkes process and its extensions, including the nonlinear Hawkes process. To date, the limit theorems for this model are restricted to large time asymptotics, and they have been well studied except the multivariate nonlinear case, which will be investigated in this research. The investigator intends to understand the large asymptotics on a fixed time interval, which will be very useful in the context of many applications. These large asymptotics will differ from the Poisson process and phase transitions are anticipated. The investigator will also study the fluctuations and large deviations of the mean-field limit of a multivariate Hawkes process when the dimension is large, which is useful in applications to neural networks, financial networks, and others. The project will also explore the spatial Hawkes processes, the space-time Hawkes processes, and other types of self-exciting point processes that have been suggested for modeling but still lack some key theoretical results. The investigator also aims to study applications of the self-exciting point processes, including theoretical applications to queueing theory and to fitting these models to real world big data sets, which requires a better understanding of some theoretical aspects of the simulations and calibrations of self-exciting point processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this project, the PI studied a class of self-exciting point processes called Hawkes processes, both in theory and applications. Point processes are well studied objects in probability theory and the subject of powerful tools in statistics for modeling and analyzing temporal and spatial data. They are useful to model the complex systems in sociology, biology, criminology, seismology, finance and many other fields. The most standard point process is the Poisson process that has independent time increments. However, one does not often observe independent time increments from the real world data. For example, during the Great Recession, credit defaults have the contagion effect and a default of one company can trigger more companies to default; In social networks, the possibility for users to re-share the content posted by their social connections may cascade across the system; In seismology, after an earthquake hits, the area often experiences aftershocks and more are expected to come; In criminology, gang-related violence has the property that a murder or shooting by one gang often provokes retaliation by another gang. All the examples above have one thing in common, the self-exciting property, that is, an event can trigger more events to come. Self-exciting point processes are a class of point processes that can exhibit the self-exciting, clustering and contagion phenomena. Despite its importance in applications, many key theoretical results are still unknown in this field.

During the project, the PI made contributions to both theory and applications. The PI made contributions to understand how the complex systems of a self-exciting point process behave like, how the microscopic properties lead to the macroscopic behaviors, and how to measure the strength of self-exciting and clustering effects. The PI also made contributions to better understanding of the large time behavior of self-exciting point processes. In particular, the PI investigated following theoretical properties of Hawkes processes. The PI studied various asymptotics of the Hawkes model, including the fluctuations and large deviations for Markovian linear Hawkes processes with a large initial intensity, the fluctuations for large baseline intensity Hawkes processes, the fluctuations and large deviations for the mean process for a multivariate nonlinear Hawkes process in high dimensions. The PI also used the mod phi convergence theory to study the large time expansions up to arbitrary order for the linear Hawkes processes and affine point processes, a related class of self-exciting point processes. The PI also made contributions to calibrations of the Hawkes model from the real world data. The Hawkes model and other self-exciting mathematical models are continuous-time in nature, but the real world data can only be observed discretely. The PI made contributions to calibrate continuous-time Markovian linear Hawkes and related models from discrete monitoring of data.

The results of the project find many applications. For example, the PI applied the self-exciting point process to study the queueing models. The asymptotic results serve as approximations to the models that are otherwise not analytically tractable. The PI also applied the asymptotic results to study the ruin probabilities from insurance applications. The theoretical contributions also shed light on the mechanisms of dark pool trading in finance and help analyze various performance metrics. These are just a few examples of the direct applications of the results of the project.

The results of the project have the broader impact to the society beyond the examples already mentioned. The project outcomes can help the researchers and the general public to better understand how the complex systems cluster and self-excite. They will help improve, refine, and offer a better understanding of existing applications of self-exciting point processes in neuroscience, machine learning, networks, insurance, finance and many other fields. They will also inspire the new applications in the future both in academia and general society.
